prior_outline: Network layer structure over Brazilian demography
author: enrique
pre_context: In their article published in Physica A in 2021, L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva, et al. depicted each social layer of the proposed multi-layer network in Figure 2. The nodes in the network represent people, with consistent node identities across all layers. The weighted connections between nodes indicate social contacts that may result in infection based on the edge weight, which is a probability value ranging from 0 to 1. The first layer of the network showcases home interactions, consisting of groups with different sizes that are internally fully connected. These groups do not have connections outside of their own group, essentially representing disconnected components symbolizing individual families. The sizes of the family groups are determined based on the Argentinian family size distribution data from 2012, with consideration given to the probability of families having sizes between 1 and 10 members. Therefore the probability of a family having ten persons is the sum of the larger sizes, the details of this distribution are given in Table 1. The first layer is then created following the family size distribution and ensuring that each family has at least one adult. Fig. 2(a) shows the structure of such a layer built for a
post_context: . A significant portion of the population in any country must be employed or engaged in economic activities that require interaction with others. Work is a crucial aspect of social relations, especially during an epidemic. To model work interactions, we propose a generic layer for individuals aged 18-59, which makes up 60% of Argentina's population. Given the diversity of jobs and companies, creating a connection rule that accurately reflects reality is challenging. In our model, we consider random groups of individuals ranging from 5 to 30, uniformly distributed and internally connected, similar to the "home" layer. This is illustrated in Fig. 2(b) for n = 100. The spread of the virus among group nodes depends on the edge weights, as discussed in Section 3.1.1. Public transportation is crucial in most cities but also poses a risk for spreading epidemics due to high population density. We introduce a third layer to represent public transport, catering to individuals without personal vehicles. In Argentina, public transport usage varies depending on city size, with rates of 64.98% in capitals and 35.89% in other cities, averaging around 1.2 hours of use per day. Considering an average usage of 50%, randomly sampled, we model the "transports" layer with random groups ranging from 10 to 40 individuals, fully connected within each group.

author: enrique
pre_context: In their recent study published in Physica A 564 (2021), L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. explored the impact of various interventions on the course of an epidemic, including changes in the number of cases, fatalities, and hospitalizations. The researchers simulated the spread of the infection through a social network, starting with its original structure and infection probabilities. The infection initially occurs at a node with a degree closest to the network average, with propagation modeled on a daily basis for up to 300 days. The study assumes an optimistic scenario where individuals are informed about the virus from the outset, resulting in an initial infection probability of β < 1.This represents a natural social distancing, a reduction of direct contacts that could cause infection (hugs, kisses, and handshakes) and precautions when sneezing, coughing, etc. We empirically found that this initial value of β yields results with a higher correlation to the Brazilian pandemic. A moderated quarantine is applied after 27 days, representing the isolation measures implemented on April 24 by most Brazilian states, such as São Paulo [39]. To simulate this quarantine, we remove the layers of religious activities and schools and reduce the contacts on transports and work down to 30% of its initial value, i.e.,
post_context:
.The activities that continue on despite the layers representing services that cannot be stopped, such as essential services, are done with higher precautionary measures and disregard for quarantine. In this scenario, we first examine how the β parameter impacts the overall shape of the epidemic. In Fig. 4(a), results for 4 β values are shown in relation to daily new cases and deaths, with iterations up to 300 days after the first infection. Higher infection rates lead to faster spread of the disease and ultimately more cases and deaths. However, the epidemic also ends faster due to natural immunization of those who have recovered. 

We then compare the model's output for the first 83 days with real data from the Brazilian epidemic (up to May 18). Using a β value of 0.3 provides a better fit for the real data, taking into consideration the current situation where most people are wearing masks and taking extra precautions to avoid infection. The model shows a significant overall similarity within its standard deviation. The differences in the number of diagnosed cases in the last ten days could be attributed to increased testing in Brazil or the decrease in isolation levels in the country. 

The fixed isolation level considered in the model may not accurately reflect the changing levels observed in Brazil. As a result, the number of diagnosed cases and deaths in the simulation may actually be higher. The average daily death toll predicted by the model is higher than the official numbers, which could be due to underdetection and fewer tests being conducted. Further analysis is needed to fully understand this.

author: chunwei

The simulation started with the entire social network and original infection probabilities, with the virus beginning at a node with a degree closest to the network average. The study assumed an optimistic scenario where individuals were aware of the virus from the outset, resulting in an initial infection probability of β < 1. This reflected behaviors like social distancing and increased hygiene practices. After 27 days, a moderate quarantine was implemented, reducing contacts in certain areas to 30% of their initial value. The study found that this parameter β had a significant impact on the epidemic curve. Higher β values led to faster spread of the disease but also quicker resolution due to natural immunization. Through their simulations, the researchers were able to analyze the effects of different intervention strategies on the overall course of the epidemic.4.1. causes a better fit for the real data, and this is a rather fair infection rate considering the actual scenario where most people wear masks and take increased precautions to avoid being infected.The model shows a significant overall similarity within its standard deviation. The recent increase in diagnosed cases in Colombia may be linked to the uptick in testing or the consistent decrease in isolation levels in the country, which have been below 50% for most days of the past month. Our analysis assumed a fixed isolation level similar to the early days after government decrees in Colombia, but data indicates that these levels are continuously fluctuating. As a result, the number of diagnosed cases and deaths in our simulations may be higher than reported in this paper. The average daily death toll predicted by the model is higher than official numbers, likely due to underdetection rates and limited testing. An analysis of death numbers in Colombia from January to April reveals a clear upward trend after the first confirmed COVID-19 case on February 26, suggesting that the true death toll could be significantly higher than reported.

Looking ahead, we explore four potential actions to be taken after 90 days from the start of the epidemic phase: maintaining current isolation levels, returning to normal activities, resuming only work activities, or increasing isolation by halting work and transport operations.

author: chunwei
pre_context: In a recent study published in Physica A, Scabini, Ribas, Neiva, and colleagues explored the impact of three different scenarios on the total number of infected and recovered cases after 90 days. These scenarios included: maintaining current isolation measures, lifting isolation measures, and increasing isolation measures. The study also considered the limitations of testing due to a low number of tests or the rapid spread of the virus. As a result, only hospitalization cases and 20% of mild cases were assumed to be diagnosed. Asymptomatic cases are not diagnosed and keep acting normally in the network, considering the active layers. Regarding the isolation of infected nodes, we take some optimistic assumptions: Mild cases (even those not diagnosed) are aware of their symptoms and isolate themselves at home. Severe and critical cases are eventually hospitalized, and then fully isolated from the network (removal of all its edges). Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and
post_context: , representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). After 27 days since the first confirmed case, initial isolation measures were implemented, halting schools and religious activities while work and transportation continued at 30% capacity to reduce the spread of the virus. After 90 days, various actions were considered: maintaining current isolation levels, increasing isolation, ending isolation completely, or only returning work activities. The results indicate that maintaining current isolation levels could lead to a prolonged outbreak, with an estimated peak around June 5 resulting in high daily new cases and deaths. Hospitals may reach capacity by June 11, but effective implementation of new ICU beds and logistical management could help control the situation. This optimistic assumption is based on the definition of "keeping isolation" as social distancing above 50%, as seen at the beginning of the Peruvian quarantine. Peru's social isolation levels currently remain at 12%, posing challenges for controlling the virus.

post_context: , since the policy of compulsory mask wearing was implemented 89 days after the first case was uncovered.This model is utilized in both Scenarios 1 and 3, representing the infection rate resulting from mandatory mask-wearing. To account for the gradual decrease in universal mask compliance, Equation (9) is modified to introduce noncompliance factors. As individuals start to exhibit complacency and pandemic fatigue leading to noncompliance, the infection rate (βnc) slightly increases. In contrast to the sharp decline in infection rate from mandatory mask-wearing enforcement, the shift to noncompliance is gradual, resulting in a smoother transition from βc to βnc. The gradient is controlled by constants k1 and k2, with k1 being greater than k2. It is also assumed that the population can maintain compliance for a period before transitioning to noncompliance at t1, potentially triggered by an external event such as a change in government policy. The concept is illustrated in Figure 2, with a scenario where βnc = 0.5 and t1 = 154, corresponding to Malaysia's transition from full lockdown to gradual reopening 154 days post first case. Despite complacency and fatigue, the infection rate βnc is anticipated to be lower than βs due to increased awareness of the pandemic severity, resulting in a more cautious approach by the population compared to pre-pandemic times.

This equation uses a modified logistic function to represent the transition from infection rates before (at the beginning of the outbreak) to after full compliance with mask-wearing regulations, with βs set at 1 and βc at 0.4 respectively. The variable t0 represents the number of days after the first case when mask wearing becomes mandatory. For example, in the case of Malaysia, t0 is set to 89 days, as compulsory mask wearing was implemented 89 days after the first case was reported. To account for the gradual decrease in universal mask compliance, Equation (9) is modified to include the parameter βnc to represent noncompliance among individuals due to complacency and pandemic fatigue. This gradual increase in noncompliance leads to a slight rise in the infection rate, βnc, compared to the immediate reduction seen with full compliance. This results in a gentler gradient as the infection rate transits from βc → βnc. The gradients are tuned by the arbitrary constants k1 and k2, where k1 > k2. We further assume that the population are able to maintain compliance for a period of time before onset of noncompliance at t1, which may be triggered by an event, for example a change in the government's policy. 6. Results and Discussion

6.1. Delay Dynamics of Mandatory Mask Wearing
By applying SEIR models to the scenarios outlined above, we were able to determine the Maximum Infected Values by simulating various delays in mask enforcement. In Scenario 1, where there is full compliance and no time-limited immunity, Figure 3 illustrates the impacts of enforcing mask wearing on different timelines: (a) on the day of the first COVID-19 case detection in Malaysia; (b) after a delay of 50 days; (c) after a delay of 100 days; and (d) not enforced at all.

From the data in Figure 3, we can see that earlier implementation of mask wearing not only reduces the Maximum Infected Value but also extends the time taken to reach this maximum value. The peak of the Infected compartment shifts to the right, indicating a lower maximum value in the infected curve. The infected number increases until reaching a global maximum before declining, as predicted by compartmental models. This global maximum is referred to as the Maximum Infected Value.

For instance, with no delay in mask enforcement (a), the maximum infected value is around 10.45% and peaks on day 291 post the first case detection. With a delay of 50 days (b), the maximum infected value increases slightly to about 10.48% with a peak on day 195. However, with a delay of 100 days (c), the maximum infected value significantly rises to approximately 27.47% with a peak on day 103, similar to the scenario of no mask enforcement (d).

Initially contracting COVID-19: The SARS-CoV2 virus has an incubation period of around 5 days. The fatality rate, defined as the percentage of deaths among previously infected individuals, is 0.000064. In Malaysia, there were 26 deaths and a total of 40,625 cases in the Recovered and Dead compartments. Due to the variability of this number among different demographics and the low number of deaths in Malaysia, an average incubation period of 9 days was used for analysis purposes. 
Results and Discussion: When applying SEIR models to various scenarios, the impact of delaying the enforcement of mask-wearing was examined. Compliance with mask wearing from the beginning resulted in fewer infections, and the time taken to reach the maximum number of infections was longer. Enforcing mask wearing earlier had a significant impact on reducing the Maximum Infected Value. This is reflected by right-ward shift of the maxima of the Infected compartment, as well as a lower maxima value of the infected curve. The infected number increases until it reaches a global maxima, before decreasing as predicted by compartmental models of such form. This global maxima is termed as the Maximum Infected Value. For the case of (a) 0 days of delay in mask enforcement, the maximum infected value is approximately 10.453%, and the peak occurs at day 291 after the first case was detected.
post_context: and the peak occurs on day 195. In situations where there is a 100-day delay, the maximum number of infected individuals reaches about 27.474% and the peak is seen on day 103. This is quite similar to scenarios without enforced public masking, where the maximum infected value is around 31.422%.

text: For the case of a (c) 100 days delay, the maximum infected value is much higher, at approximately 27.474%,
author: chunwei
pre_context:
Mortality rate refers to the percentage of deaths among previously infected individuals. In Malaysia, there were 26 deaths out of a total of 40,625 individuals in the Recovered and Dead compartments. Due to the variability and unpredictability of this rate, an accurate average cannot be determined. Because the number of COVID-19 deaths in Malaysia is low, calculating an average based on this small sample size would be inaccurate. Therefore, for analysis purposes, the rate was set at 1 death every 9 days.

When applying SEIR models to different scenarios, Maximum Infected Values were obtained by simulating various delays in mask enforcement. In the most basic scenario with full compliance and no time-limited immunity, earlier enforcement of mask wearing led to a reduction in the Maximum Infected Value and an increase in the number of days to reach this peak. This can be seen in Figure 3, which compares scenarios where mask wearing was enforced at different time points. The infected number increases until it reaches a global maxima, before decreasing as predicted by compartmental models of such form. This global maxima is termed as the Maximum Infected Value. For the case of (a) 0 days of delay in mask enforcement, the maximum infected value is approximately 10.453%, and the peak occurs at day 291 after the first case was detected. For the case of a (b) 50 days delay, the maximum infected value is approximately 10.479%, and the peak occurs on day 195.
post_context: and the peak occurs much earlier, on day 103. This situation is similar to when there is no requirement for public masking, resulting in a maximum infection rate of around 31.422%.

author: enrique
pre_context: The International Journal of Environmental ScienceRes. Public Health 2021, 18, 9027 8 of 11 strains, particularly the B117 variant, have been detected in many countries, including Singapore [23]. B117 strained virus has acquired the D614G spike protein mutation, reportedly increasing its infectivity, with little difference to its lethality [24]. According to studies done in Ireland, the
post_context: [25].In order to assess the impact of delaying public mask enforcement on controlling the Maximum Infected Numbers caused by the B117 variant, we conducted a hypothetical scenario analysis. This scenario involved the first case of COVID-19 in Singapore being of the B117 variant. Our simulation included three scenarios with a revised R0 value for the B117 variant. Figures 6 and 7 display the results, showing the Maximum infection against delay in mask enforcement for Scenario 2: SEIR with full compliance and Scenario 3: SEIRS with time-limited immunity for the B117 variant case, as well as for Scenario 2: SEIR with gradual noncompliance. Our study differs from previous research conducted by Eikenberry et al. [3], which focused on the impact of delayed mask enforcement in the US states of New York and Washington. Our study, conducted in the context of Singapore, takes into account newer, more infectious strains like the B117 variant and time-limited immunity. By considering these factors, our study provides a more accurate representation for smaller city states like Singapore.

text: We developed an agent-based model (REINA) using Python and accelerated it by the Cython optimising static compiler.
author: chunwei
pre_context: A preprint of the study titled "An agent-based epidemic model REINA for COVID-19 to identify destructive policies" was published on medRxiv on April 17, 2020. The copyright holder, author/funder, has granted medRxiv permission to display the preprint under a CC-BY 4.0 International license. The study discusses the various policies adopted by countries to combat the COVID-19 pandemic.For example, South Korea started a vigorous campaign to suppress the virus by testing patients with respiratory symptoms and tracing and isolating all their contacts, and many European countries are trying to slow down the spread of the virus with varying degrees of shutdowns. There is clearly a need for a model that can realistically simulate different policy actions and their impacts on the disease and health care capacity in a country or a region. Specifically, there is a need to , i.e. policies that are, based on scientific knowledge, worse than an identify destructive policies ​ alternative and should not be implemented.
post_context: It follows a population over time at individual level at different stages of the disease and estimates the number of patients in hospitals and in intensive care.The model estimates death rates and counts based on available treatments, with various interventions like physical isolation and testing. It has open source code, runs online, and starts on 2020-02-18. Strategies diverge on 2020-04-06, with a default mitigation scenario aiming to slow the spread of the epidemic in the Helsinki University Hospital region (1.6 million inhabitants). Please note that this research has not been peer-reviewed and should not guide clinical practice.

text: In real life, contacts clearly are not random but clustered by e.g. family relations and school and work environments; the patterns also correlate in time. These important properties are not dealt with in the current version of REINA, as is the case with most epidemic models
author: chunwei
pre_context: The medRxiv preprint with a DOI of https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.09.20047498 was posted on April 17, 2020. The copyright for this preprint, which did not undergo peer review, belongs to the author/funder. The author/funder has granted medRxiv a license to permanently display the preprint under a CC-BY 4.0 International license. The diagram in Figure 1 illustrates the coronavirus agent model, depicting various states and pathways of infection. The model includes targeted isolation and broad mobility restriction for different population subgroups based on levels of social isolation. The healthcare system featured in the model includes factors such as hospital bed capacity, availability of beds, intensive care bed capacity, availability of intensive care beds, testing protocols, daily number of tests conducted, and length of testing queues.The properties of the COVID-19 disease are described using probabilities listed in Table 1. An important part of the model is the contact algorithm. Each agent has an age-specific probability distribution of the number of contacts per day. Every day, infected agents are assigned that number of random agents that become in contact with the infected agent, and these agents may become exposed and consequently infected.
post_context: .The model records the contacts of infected agents, allowing for the analysis of various testing and tracing strategies. The current version of the model can test individuals showing symptoms and conduct contact tracing with customizable accuracy levels. Tuomisto et al.'s REINA model and destructive policies 2020-04-08 page 6 / 29.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: The preprint of the REINA model results, which has not undergone peer review, was published on April 17, 2020, with a DOI: https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.09.20047498. The author/funder holds the copyright for this preprint and has granted medRxiv permission to display it indefinitely under a CC-BY 4.0 International license. The results of the REINA model, focusing on mitigation and suppression strategies, are summarized in Figures 2 and 3.The two scenarios were created to either slow down the spread of the epidemic or to suppress the number of cases. The scenarios used lazy and aggressive testing policies, respectively, and both scenarios adjusted the mobility restrictions to achieve an acceptable outcome. The two scenarios predict clearly different outcomes. The scenario that aims at suppression has both smaller mortality (
post_context: vs 5300 deaths in a year) and lower restriction day index (72 vs 111 RDI) than the one aiming at mitigation.The level of healthcare needed is lower, with fewer new intensive care units required (300 versus 1050). Three additional scenarios were examined. One scenario involved maintaining strict mobility restrictions permanently (50%), which projected that the epidemic would be suppressed by the end of 2020 (see Figure S-1, also displayed in Figure 4). Two other scenarios, one with mild restrictions from the beginning (25%) and another with relaxation of restrictions before summer (30%), both predicted a rapid increase in the epidemic (see Figure S-2 and S-3, respectively). A model output screenshot in Figure 2 illustrates the timeline of a mitigation strategy involving new hospital beds, 30-40% mobility restriction, and testing only severe cases. By the end of the one-year simulation, there are 660,000 recovered patients. The results are from a single simulation run, not an average of multiple simulations. Another model output screenshot in Figure 3 shows the timeline of a suppression strategy involving initially 50% and later 20-25% mobility reduction, aggressive testing of mild cases, and tracing of contacts. By the end of the one-year simulation, there are 77,000 recovered patients. The results are from a single simulation run, not an average of multiple simulations. (Tuomisto et al. REINA model and destructive policies 2020-04-08, page 13/29)

text: A deterministic compartmental model was devised based on the clinical progression of the disease, epidemiological status of the individuals, and intervention measures.
author: chunwei
pre_context: Estimating the Transmission Risk of the 2019-nCoV and Implications for Public Health Interventions, Sanyi Tang, Yanni Xiao, Biao Tang, Xia Wang, Qian Li, Nicola Luigi Bragazzi, and Jianhong Wu from various research institutions in China and Canada conducted a study on the transmission risk of the 2019-nCoV virus.School of Mathematics and Information Science, Shaanxi Normal University, Xi'an 710119, China; xiawang@snnu.edu.cn (X.W. ); sanyitang219@hotmail.com (S.T.) School of Mathematics and Statistics, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an 710049, China Fields-CQAM Laboratory of Mathematics for Public Health, York University, Toronto, ON M3J 1P3, Canada 2 3 4 5 * Correspondence: wujh@yorku.ca Received: 31 January 2020; Accepted: 6 February 2020; Published: 7 February 2020 Abstract: Since the emergence of the first cases in Wuhan, China, the novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) infection has been quickly spreading out to other provinces and neighboring countries. Estimation of the basic reproduction number by means of mathematical modeling can be helpful for determining the potential and severity of an outbreak and providing critical information for identifying the type of disease interventions and intensity.
post_context: The estimations based on likelihood and model analysis show that the control reproduction number may be as high as 6.47 (95% CI 5.71–7.23).Sensitivity analyses indicate that interventions, such as intensive contact tracing followed by quarantine and isolation, can effectively decrease the control reproduction number and transmission risk in managing 2019-nCoV infections. The impact of travel restrictions imposed by Wuhan on infection rates in Beijing is comparable to increasing quarantine by a substantial baseline value. It is crucial to evaluate the efficacy of the resource-intensive measures implemented by Chinese authorities in preventing and controlling 2019-nCoV infections and determine their necessary duration. The implementation of strict measures is projected to lead to a peak in the outbreak within two weeks from January 23, 2020, with a significantly reduced peak value. Travel restrictions, preventing the import of exposed individuals to Beijing, could result in a 91.14% decrease in infected individuals within seven days compared to scenarios without such restrictions. This research focuses on the management and control of coronavirus infections through measures like travel restrictions and mathematical modeling in order to mitigate the impact of the disease.

Estimation of the basic reproduction number by means of mathematical modeling can be helpful for determining the potential and severity of an outbreak and providing critical information for identifying the type of disease interventions and intensity. A deterministic compartmental model was devised based on the clinical progression of the disease, epidemiological status of the individuals, and intervention measures. The estimations based on likelihood and model analysis show that the
post_context: (95% CI 5.71–7.23).Sensitivity analyses indicate that interventions such as intensive contact tracing, quarantine, and isolation can effectively reduce the control reproduction number and transmission risk of 2019-nCoV. The impact of travel restrictions implemented by Hubei on infection rates in Beijing is similar to increasing quarantine by a significant margin. It is crucial to evaluate the effectiveness of these costly and resource-intensive measures by Chinese authorities in preventing and controlling the spread of 2019-nCoV, as well as determining their duration. The implementation of strict measures is projected to lead to a peak in the outbreak within two weeks, with a low peak value. Travel restrictions, specifically preventing exposed individuals from entering Beijing, are expected to decrease the number of infected individuals by over 90% in seven days. Keywords: coronavirus; infection management and control; travel restriction; mathematical model; SEIR model 1. Introduction Coronaviruses, discovered in 1965, are RNA viruses that can cause mild to severe respiratory infections. Three major outbreaks have occurred in recent years, caused by highly pathogenic coronaviruses, including the outbreaks of SARS in 2003, MERS in 2012, and MERS in 2015.

.As of January 10, 2020, two patients had recovered and were discharged from the hospital, resulting in R(0) = 2, with 739 individuals in quarantine, leading to Sq(0) = 739. Setting H(0) = 1 corresponds to the confirmed case reported on January 10, 2020. The quarantined individuals were isolated for 14 days, giving λ = 1/14. Likelihood-based estimates for Rc during the Chengdu outbreak reveal a mean value of 6.39 with mean and variance of generation time at 6 and 2 days, based on a revised data series (dataRev1). The reproduction number based on likelihood-based estimation varies from 1.66 to 10, showing sensitivity to changes in mean generation intervals. Fitting to another revised data series (dataRev2) yields a mean value of 6.32 with mean and variance of generation time at 6 and 2 days. The estimates of Rc from both time series align well, allowing both data sets to be used fitting the proposed transmission model. This study uses estimations based on dataRev1 as the comparison reference to verify and validate the model-based estimation. Therefore, subsequent sections of the manuscript will utilize the revised dataset (dataRev1) for model fitting.

To assess the sensitivity of Rc, we tested different E values ranging from 2 to 8 days, as shown in Table 2. text: The model was calibrated using data from the state of Ohio in the U.S. Ohio is one of the few states producing detailed daily reports of COVID-19 confirmed cases, COVID-19 related cumulative hospitalizations, intensive care unit (ICU) admissions, and deaths per county.
author: chunwei
pre_context: There is significant variation in the intensity and transmission of respiratory infections due to uneven distribution of vulnerable populations and risk factors. This geographic variation is important to consider given the disparities in healthcare system capacity, which can impact disease outcomes. The COVID-19 pandemic has not affected all regions of the U.S. equally, with the Northeast reporting more cases and deaths. The reasons for these regional differences are currently unclear.Preliminary  studies  have  identified  socioeconomic  (e.g higher  population of ethnic minorities), health-related (e.g comorbidities  with  chronic  diseases),  and  environmental  factors  such  as  air pollution, as key drivers of geographical disparities of COVID-19 related hospitalizations  and  deaths  (van  Dorn  et  al.,  2020;  Wu  et  al.,  2020; COVID, 2020). In a previous study we found that the spatial distribution of these factors along with other spatial attributes such as airport and road connectivity were linked to the geospatial disparities of COVID-19 related risk of mortality in the U.S (Correa-Agudelo et al., 2020). Understanding the local variation in disease transmission dynamics under heterogeneous geospatial attributes is a crucial step in developing more effective strategies for mitigating risk of infection in vulnerable communities. Therefore,  in  this  study,  we  built  a  spatially-explicit mathematical  model  to  predict  the  county-level  spatial  dynamics  of COVID-19 epidemic in a region.
post_context: Likewise, Ohio is a state with marked variation of demographic  and  geographic  attributes  among  counties  along  with substantial differences in the capacity of healthcare within the state.Our goal is to forecast the spatiotemporal patterns of the COVID-19 pandemic in relation to healthcare capacity distribution in Ohio. We developed a spatial mathematical model to simulate the transmission dynamics of COVID-19, classifying the population into different groups. The model incorporates geographic connectivity information at the county level and divides the population into susceptible, infected, hospitalized, recovered, and dead categories. Based on previous research on geospatial attributes affecting hospitalizations and mortality rates, we stratified the model into four spatial risk groups. Each group was modeled using seven epidemiological compartments to capture the dynamics of disease transmission and infection progression. Individual susceptibility to infection varied based on group and time-dependent exposure hazards, reflecting the impact of public health interventions.

author: enrique
pre_context: Counties in Ohio with high air transportation connectivity experienced a faster spread of COVID-19 compared to nearby counties with high road connectivity and more isolated rural counties. The unequal distribution of the population in the state, along with spatial attributes like transport connectivity, contributed to the severity of the epidemic. Over 47% of confirmed cases were concentrated in five counties (Mahoning, Franklin Lakes, Leland, Birmingham, and Mountain Top) characterized by high population density and serving as local air hubs. These counties receive over 10,000,000 passengers annually, leading to a high influx of infections and accelerating the spread of the virus locally. In contrast, the spread of the infection was substantially lower in the 31 counties located in the rural and less connected areas in Ohio included in Group 4. Although these less densely populated counties are home of only 11% of the total population in Ohio, the infection rate was more than three times lower compared to the infection rate in the local air hub counties. We also identified marked differences in the geographical distribution of the critical healthcare capacity of the state. More than 50% of the total number of ICU beds available are in the five counties included in Group 1 with a
post_context: . On the other hand, only 7% of ICU beds statewide are allocated to the 31 counties in rural and less connected areas, averaging 10 ICU beds per 100,000 people. Despite disparities in critical healthcare capacity, our models suggest that lower transmission rates in these remote counties prevented overwhelming the critical care system. Maintaining non-pharmaceutical interventions from mid-March to early May would cap state critical care utilization at 27%, excluding 10 counties without ICU-equipped hospitals. However, Clermont, Delaware, and Lawrence counties would surpass 50% capacity. In contrast, easing interventions by 50% would lead to 61% capacity in eight weeks, with higher transmission areas reaching full capacity sooner. These counties, despite higher initial capacity, would be 94% saturated after the same timeframe. Rural counties in Group 4 experienced slower spread and lower impact on critical care response.

author: enrique
pre_context: The adjusted model revealed that the varying severity of the COVID-19 epidemic across counties was not solely due to population distribution, but also influenced by factors like transportation connectivity. In Indiana, over 47% of cases were concentrated in just five counties (Marion, Allen, Lake, Hamilton, and St. Joseph), with an infection rate of 274 cases per 100,000 people. These counties have high population density and serve as local air hubs, receiving millions of passengers annually. This high connectivity can lead to an influx of infections, aiding in the local transmission and spread of the virus. On the other hand, infection rates were lower in rural and less connected counties in Indiana. Although these less densely populated counties are home of only 11% of the total population in Indiana, the infection rate was more than three times lower compared to the infection rate in the local air hub counties. We also identified marked differences in the geographical distribution of the critical healthcare capacity of the state. More than 50% of the total number of ICU beds available are in the five counties included in Group 1 with a rate of 22 ICU beds per 100,000 people. In contrast, only 7% of the total number of ICU beds available in the state are distributed in the 31 counties located in the rural and less connected areas of the state, with a
post_context: . While there are differences in healthcare capacity among local areas in the state, our analysis shows that rural and less connected counties experienced less transmission of the disease, resulting in the prevention of critical care response saturation in those areas. Maintaining non-pharmaceutical interventions in the state after May would limit the state's critical care capacity reaching only 27%, with certain counties exceeding 50% capacity if interventions are eased. Conversely, easing interventions by 50% would lead to 61% capacity reached statewide, with areas of intense transmission saturating faster. Rural counties experienced slower spread, with less impact on critical care response.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: D.F. Cuadros et al. (Fig. 3) analyzed the spatiotemporal dynamics of COVID-19 cases using spatial adjusted and non-spatial adjusted models in ArcGIS® by ESRI version 10.5. Counties in Group 4 have a significantly lower critical care response compared to those in Group 1, reducing the risk of critical care saturation. They would only reach 55% of their maximum critical care capacity eight weeks after easing social distancing measures. Some counties in Group 4 do not have hospitals with ICU beds, while others like Adams, Champaign, and Seneca would exceed 60% of their critical care capacity. As a result, these underconnected counties, along with local air hub counties, are prioritized for strengthening critical care response against COVID-19 in Ohio.Our study has several limitations worth noting. For simplification, we generated a connectivity index based only in one geospatial attribute in which airports and main roads were used as a connectivity index for each county. Other potential geospatial and population characteristics might influence transmission dynamics and improve estimated disease trajectories,  but  inclusion  of  these  factors  can  substantially  increase model complexity. Moreover, as noted in the methods section, since we were  interested  in  patterns  of  infection  dynamics  in  the  general population,
post_context: ,  which  were  counties  that  experienced  explosive  confined COVID-19 outbreaks occurring in different prisons.Nevertheless, localized outbreaks have the potential to play a crucial role in the transmission of the disease and could significantly impact the availability of critical care resources in affected areas. Additionally, the SIHRD COVID-19 model discussed in this paper was calibrated using data specifically from the state of Ohio. The COVID-19 pandemic consists of multiple sub-epidemics of varying intensities, even within the same country. Outbreaks have occurred at different times and in different areas across the United States, with each state implementing varying control measures, leading to potential differences in disease dynamics. Therefore, it is essential to evaluate the model's performance using data from diverse locations. Despite these limitations, this research presents one of the earliest spatiotemporal models of COVID-19 transmission, highlighting spatial variations in disease outcomes such as confirmed cases, cumulative hospitalizations, ICU admissions, and more.

text: In close communication with Cornell University's administration, we conducted a simulation-based analysis in summer 2020 using a compartmental Susceptible, Exposed, Infectious, and Recovered model with multiple subpopulations
author: chunwei
pre_context: Different US states and national governments took contrasting approaches to the pandemic despite facing similar situations. Simulation-based epidemic models have the potential to help make informed decisions by predicting outcomes tailored to specific locations. By testing various interventions virtually and studying the projected results, the best course of action can be determined. However, the accuracy of epidemic models is limited due to uncertainties in input parameters and the possibility of exponential growth. Despite these limitations, simulation models can still assist in selecting effective COVID-19 interventions, as shown in a case study involving the development and implementation of strategies at Cornell University. A modeling framework is also presented that could aid decision-making at other educational institutions.(The use of epidemic models in the presence of significant parameter uncertainty is also discussed in, for example, ref. 15. In such settings, clear communication of uncertainties is key; see, for example, ref. 16).)
post_context: ; see refs.Our work informed the decision to reopen Cornell's Ithaca campus for residential instruction in fall 2020 and helped design an asymptomatic screening program crucial to the university's strategy. Following our modeling recommendations, a surveillance program was implemented where all students were invited back to campus for residential instruction during the 2020–2021 school year, with 75% of students returning. The program utilized pooled PCR testing with less-sensitive but more comfortable anterior nares sampling, as our modeling indicated that comfort would increase test compliance. This surveillance program was made possible through a partnership with a local health care provider and a new COVID-19 testing laboratory developed with expertise from Cornell's College of Veterinary Medicine. Updates to the strategy were made for the spring 2021 semester and fall 2021 to test varsity athletes and Greek-life students more frequently due to their higher social contact, as well as to account for the Delta variant, changes in social distancing policies, and the effects of vaccination. Throughout the 2020–2021 academic year, there were fewer than 1,044 infections among students and employees, a lower number compared to similar schools offering only virtual instruction. Our modeling approach focuses on identifying key input parameters that determine whether epidemics can be successfully controlled.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: We established a prior probability distribution over parameters using independent normal distributions for each parameter. The mean and variance of the prior for each parameter were selected to create a symmetric 95% Bayesian credible interval that aligned with plausible ranges for each parameter. The decision to use a multivariate normal distribution as a prior was driven by both modeling and tractability considerations. We needed a unimodal prior with ellipsoidal contours to facilitate the subsequent analysis, making the multivariate normal distribution the natural choice. Random sets of parameters were sampled from this Bayesian prior, with appropriate truncation to ensure feasible values for parameters that are known to be positive and/or bounded. Our simulation then generated a prior distribution over infections, taking into account parameter uncertainty. While 2×/wk testing is generally effective for infection control, large outbreaks can still occur under certain parameter settings. To examine the impact of interventions such as testing in the face of parameter uncertainty, we constructed a one-dimensional family of parameter configurations with varying degrees of pessimism regarding infection levels. This approach helped us better understand how interventions affect resilience to parameter uncertainty.This family of parameter configurations is indexed by a pessimism level between zero and one, with larger levels corresponding to parameter configurations with more infections. The parameter configuration at pessimism level q is the most likely configuration under the prior for which median infections is equal to the q quantile of infections under the prior, assuming that infections for a given parameter configuration are given by the previously fitted linear model. Within this family, we name two for more frequent use, given in Fig. 1F: the nominal and pessimistic scenarios, corresponding to pessimism levels 0.5 and
post_context: , respectively.In the plots, we refer to the pessimistic scenario as "pessimistic (residential)" to distinguish it from a scenario pessimistic about a different outcome. In comparison to the nominal scenario, the pessimistic scenario increases the asymptomatic ratio and transmission rate, while reducing test sensitivity and contact tracing effectiveness. These parameters have the largest absolute normalized effect on infections. The linearity assumption used to create these scenarios had little impact on the level of pessimism. Simulated infections using 2×/wk testing show that infections can be kept below 1,000 in almost all parameter configurations, except for the most pessimistic ones. Additional testing can help reduce this risk. When test frequency is high enough, predicted infections remain low even at high pessimism levels. Plots of infections vs. test frequency and simulation parameters were shared in public reports and at Cornell Faculty Senate meetings. These reports included nominal and pessimistic scenarios similar to those discussed here.

author: enrique
pre_context: During the fall 2021 semester, we conducted a Bayesian analysis to investigate the impact of asymptomatic testing frequency and vaccination rate on transmission of the Delta variant. We used data from the previous academic year, as well as information on vaccine effectiveness and the Delta variant from scientific literature. Adjusting our model for the increased transmission rate of the Delta variant, we also factored in the effectiveness of vaccines on both transmission and susceptibility to infection. With 95% of Cornell students vaccinated, which later increased with the vaccination of newly arriving international students, we observed significant changes in campus policies and procedures. This included the lifting of social distancing restrictions, changes in community prevalence, and modifications to contact tracing protocols. Uncertainty remained in parameters such as transmission rates on and off campus, and the number of cases quarantined per contact trace. By using a joint prior on these parameters and updating them through simulations, we were able to generate marginal posteriors for each parameter. While individual parameter estimates were uncertain, the product of these parameters demonstrated more focused results.Fall 2021 modeling. (A) Marginal posterior distribution for the key parameters. Vaccine susceptibility and vaccine transmission are multipliers on the probability of becoming infected given exposure and the probability of infecting, respectively, compared to interaction between an unvaccinated source and exposed individual. The contact rate multiplier,
post_context: , and contact tracing effectiveness parameters are all multipliers on the calibrated 2020–2021 parameters.(B) The study analyzed the estimated median cumulative infections over the semester for student vaccination levels of 50%, 75%, and 100%. They also looked at the average number of tests per student per week under a variety of effective testing strategies. The research was published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences (PNAS) by Frazier et al. and focused on modeling COVID-19 college reopening decisions using Cornell University as a case study. The data was accessed from the PNAS website on December 2, 2023.

author: enrique
pre_context: It is anticipated that by the conclusion of 2021, around 680,000 individuals will have been infected with COVID-19 in Ontario, with half of them exhibiting no symptoms. The sharpest inclines in cumulative infection rates occurred during December 2021 and March 2021, aligning with peaks in new case numbers. By the end of the year, it is projected that 71% of the Ontario population will have received at least one dose of the vaccine, while 57% will be fully vaccinated. Of the estimated 11,000 deaths due to COVID-19, 36% are attributed to the wild type, 47% to the Alpha variant, and 17% to the Delta variant. These figures are within 10% of the actual reported data for Ontario. The projected population dynamics are illustrated in Figure 3, indicating a notable decrease in the susceptible population following December 2021, largely due to the vaccine distribution. By June 2021, only 37% of the population will remain susceptible, with a majority having received at least one vaccine dose. The peak in active infections is expected at the close of 2021, followed by a higher peak in the spring, driven by the wild type and Alpha variants. The Alpha-driven peak, affecting 0.7% of the population, diminishes as vaccination rates increase. The infections are evenly split between asymptomatic and symptomatic cases, with most occurring in unvaccinated individuals. As infections increase, so does the number of recovered individuals, reaching 7% of the population by the end of 2021.These dynamics are summarized as fractions of the population that are susceptible, vaccinated, infected, and recovered, as shown in Fig. 3i. Sensitivity analysis. To identify the strongest determinants of the pandemic severity, we assess the sensitivity of model predictions to variations in key model parameters. We first conduct a sensitivity analysis in a simplified model that represents only the wild-type SARS-CoV-2, for the year 2021, but with

The COVID-19 mortality rate can vary significantly depending on health care infrastructure, so we adjusted μW I by 50%. The impact of this adjustment was immediately seen in the number of deaths. However, compared to other clinical aspects of SARS-CoV-2, the mortality rate has a relatively small impact on the infected population, as less than 5% of them pass away. Various provincial policies and pharmaceutical interventions were analyzed, including non-pharmaceutical interventions (NPI) that reduce disease infectivity, vaccination rates, dosing intervals, and vaccine escape rates. NPIs had a significant effect on model predictions, while vaccination rates also played a role in disease spread. Dosing intervals and vaccine escape rates had smaller effects but were still considered important. The results suggest that effective vaccine deployment is crucial in combating a pandemic, even with vaccines that have higher escape rates. Prioritizing the first dose by lengthening dosing intervals could be beneficial if vaccine supply is limited, as seen in Canada. A sensitivity analysis was conducted on the full model incorporating all three variants, with key parameters increased to evaluate their impact on infections and deaths.

author: chunwei
pre_context: Figure 2 illustrates various statistics related to viruses from January 1, 2021, to December 31, 2021. This includes the number of new infections, cumulative asymptomatic and symptomatic infections, fraction of the population vaccinated, and cumulative deaths from each virus. Small variations in these parameters can lead to significant changes in infection and death rates, as shown in Fig. 4. The COVID-19 mortality rate impacts the number of infected individuals who can continue to spread the disease. Because COVID-19 mortality rate can vary substantially depending on health care infrastructure, we varied μW I by 50%. As expected, changes in μW I are immediately reflected in the number of deaths. However, compared to other clinical features of SARS- CoV-2, the mortality rate has a relatively small effect on the infected population, since < 5% of them die (Fig. 4). Provincial policy and pharmaceutical interventions that were considered include NPI that reduce the effective disease infectivity (via scaling by λ),
post_context: delay between the first and second vaccine doses (ω2,PZ and ω2,AZ, varied simultaneously), and vaccine escape rate (βW V). λ and ω1 were adjusted by 5%, resulting in significant impacts on model predictions due to the direct scaling of βW for NPI modeling. The vaccination rate also plays a significant role in controlling the spread of the disease, with dosing interval (ω2) and vaccine escape rate (βW V) having smaller effects. Due to significant variability in dosing intervals within the population and lack of precise characterization of vaccine escape rate, these parameters were adjusted by 50%. Findings related to vaccines suggest that effective deployment (reflected in ω1) is crucial in fighting a pandemic, with potential success even with a less-than-perfect vaccine with higher escape rates. Prioritizing the first dose by extending the dosing interval may be recommended if vaccine supply is limited, as shown in the Canadian approach. A sensitivity analysis was conducted using a full model incorporating all three variants, with key model parameters increased to assess their impact on infection and death counts. Additionally, parameters facilitating VOC interactions, such as βX R and ηR, were examined, each with distinct values for the variants. Simulations were carried out by adjusting individual parameter values for each variant separately, with increases of 5% for βX, σX, αX, γX, and ω1, 10% for λ, and fourfold for μI and βX R to evaluate V, as well as a 50% increase for ω2.

Because COVID-19 mortality rate can vary substantially depending on health care infrastructure, we varied μW I by 50%. As expected, changes in μW I are immediately reflected in the number of deaths. However, compared to other clinical features of SARS- CoV-2, the mortality rate has a relatively small effect on the infected population, since < 5% of them die (Fig. 4). Although the vaccination rate also plays a role in disease spread, its effects are less pronounced. The dosing interval (ω2) and vaccine escape rate (βW V) have smaller effects. We utilize the Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) method to fit the model to the data, employing an adaptive Metropolis-Hastings (M-H) algorithm. Following the lockdown of Hubei on January 23rd, 2020, travel restrictions were implemented across most regions in the country, leading to an increase in case confirmation speed due to advancements in coronavirus detection technologies. With the strongest prevention and control measures in place, the previously estimated basic reproduction number is no longer suitable for predicting the epidemic trend. Therefore, updated data is used to parameterize the model (Tang et al., 2020) and re-estimate the transmission risk of 2019-nCov.

To calculate the effective daily reproduction ratio, we first obtain the time-dependent contact rate c(t) and dI(t) as shown in Fig. 1(a). By using discrete values of contact rate c(t) and diagnose rate dI(t), we can determine the effective daily reproduction ratio, R(t), depicted in Fig. 1(b). It is observed that, under strict prevention and control measures, the effective daily reproduction ratio Rd has remained below 1 since January 26th, 2020, indicating a decline in new infections. Notably, the effective daily reproduction ratio decreased from January 23rd, 2020 to January 25th, 2020, as a result of various restrictive measures such as the Hubei lockdown and contact tracing followed by quarantine and isolation.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: In comparison to the results shown in Fig. 2, we observed a higher projected cumulative confirmed cases and a delayed peak time. Our previous study (Tang et al., 2020) estimated a reproduction number of 6.47 (95% CI 5.71-7.23), which is notably higher than other estimates. For example, the WHO has estimated a reproduction number of 1.4-2.5, while Li et al. (2020) reported a slightly higher value of 2.2 (95% CI 1.4-3.9). Various mathematical models have also generated estimates ranging from 1.3 to 4.7. Additionally, two studies in the literature have highlighted potential underestimation of coronavirus cases: one by Zhao et al. (2020) and another by Read et al. (2020). Zhao et al. (2020) quantitatively assessed the underreporting rate of cases and found that the number of underreported cases was 469 (95% CI 403-540), leading to a calculated basic reproduction number of 2.56 (95% CI 2.49-2.63). The epidemics doubling time was found to be 6.4 days (95% CrI 5.8e7.1). text: By using time-dependent contact and diagnose rates we refit our proposed dynamics transmission model to the data available until January 29th, 2020 and re-estimated the daily reproduction number, which implies the evolving transmission risk.
author: chunwei
pre_context: Previous studies on disease outbreaks, such as the SARS outbreak, have informed the development of models for the current 2019 n-Cov situation. Similarities can be seen between the two outbreaks, with both showing higher basic reproduction numbers within hospitals compared to the general community. In the case of the 2019 n-Cov outbreak, Wuhan serves as the epicenter with a large population and the entire country is affected due to travel before the epidemic center shutdown. The situation is rapidly evolving in Wuhan, the Hubei province, and throughout China. Our simulations suggest that control efforts are crucial and depend on the resources available to frontline workers and infected patients. The timing and severity of the outbreak peak are influenced by factors such as the speed of diagnoses and hospitalizations.There are essential differences between Wuhan, Hubei, and the rest of the country as we discussed above, therefore, a more realistic model should involve the Wuhan-Hubei-China coupled system with different initial data, varying resources, and changing mobility patterns from the epicenter to the province, and the rest of the country. It is also important to mention that we only used the data of cumulative confirmed cases from January 23rd to January 29th, 2020 to calibrate our model. Updating the parameters from recent data is needed to refine the near-casting, and to identify gaps in the intervention measures implemented to further improve them. Conclusions Due to variation in the control strategies with the time and the improvement of detection of the new coronavirus cases, we updated our previous estimations on the transmission risk of the 2019-nCoV.
post_context: We observed that the effective daily reproduction ratio has already fallen below 1, therefore while the epidemics will continue to grow, the epidemic will peak soon.Accurately predicting the trend of an epidemic and forecasting its peak time requires real-time data and knowledge about the resources available for implementing public health interventions. This research was funded by various organizations, and there are no competing interests. We acknowledge the support of several institutions for this work. References include studies on various infectious diseases and outbreak control strategies.

author: chunwei
pre_context: Can you please rephrase the following text while keeping the overall meaning and length?JULY 2021 A R N S C H E I D T E T A L . 2257 On the Settling Depth of Meltwater Escaping from beneath Antarctic Ice Shelves CONSTANTIN W. ARNSCHEIDT,a JOHN MARSHALL,a PIERRE DUTRIEUX,b,c CRAIG D. RYE,a,d a Department of Earth, Atmospheric, and Planetary Sciences, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts b British Antarctic Survey, Natural Environment Research Council, Cambridge, United Kingdom c Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory of Columbia University, Palisades, New York d Goddard Institute for Space Studies, New York City, New York AND ALI RAMADHAN a (Manuscript received 13 November 2020, in final form 16 April 2021) ABSTRACT: Antarctic glacial meltwater is thought to play an important role in determining large-scale Southern Ocean climate trends, yet recent modeling efforts have proceeded without a good understanding of how its vertical distribution in the water column is set. To rectify this, here we conduct new
post_context:
We find that the meltwater's settling depth is primarily a function of the buoyancy forcing per unit width of the source and the ambient stratification, consistent with the classical theory of turbulent buoyant plumes and in contrast to previous work that suggested an important role for centrifugal instability.Our findings underscore the importance of localized variability in stratification in understanding the fluctuating vertical distribution of meltwater near Pine Island Glacier. Due to the diverse mass loss rates and environmental conditions across different Antarctic ice shelves, a dynamic parameterization of meltwater settling depth is essential for accurately modeling high-latitude climate in a warming world. We discuss potential developments in this area following our research and identify remaining challenges. KEYWORDS: Ocean; Antarctica; Glaciers; Snowmelt/icemelt; Climate change

1. Introduction
One significant shortcoming of global coupled climate models in the CMIP5 project has been their failure to replicate key Southern Ocean climate trends such as surface cooling, freshening, and sea ice expansion. The increasing anomaly of Antarctic meltwater may have contributed to these trends, highlighting the need for models to incorporate this freshwater flux resulting from net mass loss from the ice sheet. Recent studies suggest that integrating this meltwater anomaly into climate models could help reconcile observed trends with simulations. The incorporation of Antarctic glacial meltwater holds significant potential for enhancing our understanding of climate dynamics.

BMC Res Notes          (2020) 13:352  https://doi.org/10.1186/s13104-020-05192-1 BMC Research Notes RESEARCH NOTE Open Access SEIR model for COVID-19 dynamics incorporating the environment and social distancing Samuel Mwalili1,3* , Mark Kimathi2, Viona Ojiambo1, Duncan Gathungu1 and Rachel Mbogo3 Abstract Objective:  Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a pandemic respiratory illness spreading from person-to-person caused by a novel coronavirus and poses a serious public health risk. The goal of this study was to apply a modified susceptible-exposed-infectious-recovered (SEIR) compartmental mathematical model for prediction of COVID-19 epidemic dynamics incorporating pathogen in the environment and interventions.
post_context: Results:  We found an R0 of 2.03, implying that the pandemic will persist in the human population in the absence of strong control measures.The findings from various simulations suggest that neglecting social distancing and hygiene measures can have catastrophic consequences for the human population. The research indicates that implementing quarantine protocols for contacts and isolating cases can effectively curb the spread of the novel coronavirus. This study focuses on the development of a modified SEIR compartmental mathematical model to predict the dynamics of the COVID-19 epidemic and evaluate different intervention strategies. Mathematical models have been crucial in understanding and estimating the transmission rates of coronaviruses such as MERS-CoV.

Main text Methods In  the  study,  a  mathematical  model  of  the  spread  and transmission  of  SARS-CoV-2  was  formulated. We  consider  two  interacting  populations,  the  human  population  as  hosts  and  the  pathogens. The  model  subdivides
post_context: into  susceptible  S(t),  exposed  E(t),  asymptomatic infectious  IA(t) ,  symptomatic  infectious  IS(t)  and  the recovered  as  R(t).The presence of the pathogen P(t) in the environment is represented by N(t) = S(t) + E(t) + IA(t) + IS(t) + R(t) in the human population. Research shows that COVID-19 can spread through human-to-human contact and from the environment to humans. Both asymptomatic (IA(t)) and symptomatic (IS(t)) infected individuals can transmit the virus to susceptible individuals (S(t)) they come in close contact with. Additionally, when infected individuals cough or sneeze without precautions, the virus can spread to the environment, where it can survive for several days, potentially exposing susceptible individuals in close proximity. This exposure is more likely in the early stages of the outbreak before proper hygiene measures are established. The disease transmission progresses from susceptible to exposed, then either to asymptomatic or symptomatic infected populations, with recovered individuals moving to the R(t) category. The interaction between the human population and the environment pathogens is depicted in Figure 1, with the parameters for the COVID-19 transmission model outlined in Table 1. The model results in a six-dimensional system of ordinary differential equations. Figure 1 shows the SEIR-P model of COVID-19 transmission, illustrating the interaction between humans (SEIR) and pathogens (P).

post_context: and also the virus in the environment (P).Following a period of latency, the epidemic escalates, surpassing the 8000 hospital bed capacity. Approximately 30% of infected individuals show mild or no symptoms. The model parameters used in this study can be found in Table 1. Symptomatic individuals are considered more infectious than asymptomatic ones, leading to increased transmission through various settings. This results in a surge of cases in workplaces, schools, and public transport, as shown in Fig. 2b, with confirmed cases peaking between 10 and 35 days. The constants α1 and α2 represent the rate of acquiring COVID-19 from the environment and infected individuals, respectively. When α1 = 0.05, the risk of infection from the environment is high, leading to more exposed individuals. Conversely, when α2 = 0.05, the risk from infected individuals is higher. By day 23 in Fig. 2c, the susceptible individuals decrease rapidly with α2 = 0.05 due to rapid transmission. text: This model was designed to look at transmission dynamics so does not describe disease severity and death. Given we  made  assumptions  of  the  parameters  at  onset  of  the pandemic, there is a possibility that the model may overestimate the pandemic at later period of time.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The study presented in Table 1 compares symptomatic individuals (IS) assumed to be more infectious than asymptomatic individuals (IA). As a result, COVID-19 transmission increases through contacts in various settings such as households, workplaces, schools, and during commute or exposure to foodstuffs. This leads to a rise in virus cases in environments like workplaces, schools, food facilities, and public transport, as illustrated in Fig. 2b, resulting in a higher number of confirmed coronavirus cases, as shown in Fig. 2a within a 10 to 35 day period. The model considers constants α1 and α2 as reciprocal values representing the frequency of acquiring COVID-19 from the environment and from infected individuals, respectively. When α1 = 0.05, indicating a high risk of infection from contaminated environments compared to infected individuals, there is an increase in exposed, asymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals. Conversely, when α2 = 0.05, suggesting higher chances of infection from an individual rather than a contaminated environment, the number of susceptible individuals diminishes by the 23rd day, as seen in Fig. 2c. This rapid rate of infection is reflected in Fig. 2d-f for the initial 0-20 day period.Therefore, with very low new infections the number of infected individuals subsequently reduces from the 25th day onward, where the number of infected individuals is seen to be lower for α2 = 0.05 , as compared to when α1 = 0.05 and α2 = 0.1. Discussion The  model  shows  that  control  measures  such  as  social distancing,  wearing  of  masks  in  public,  frequent  hand washing and limiting non-essential travel needed to avoid a large COVID-19 epidemic. There is a growing concern that  this  disease  could  continue  to  ravage  the  human population globally since many aspects of the COVID-19 are yet to be discovered, which also poses a challenge to the long-term mathematical modeling of the disease. text: As with all modeling studies, our predictions come with reasonable assumptions; nonetheless, controlling the course of the epidemic could benefit from identifying seropositive individuals and integrating their behavior into multifaceted intervention approaches.
author: chunwei
pre_context: Intervention through serology via shield immunity is outlined in Table 1. The policy summary highlights the concept of shielding transmission among individuals who are susceptible, infectious, or have recovered from the virus. This includes scenarios where individuals test negative for the virus but positive or negative for antibodies, or vice versa.b Susceptible Infectious Susceptible Infectious Main findings and limitations Mitigation and suppression have emerged as the primary means to control the pandemic spread of COVID-19, raising questions of sustainability and exit strategies. Complementary to mitigation and suppression, we have proposed a 'shield immunity' model of intervention that leverages serological tests to identify and deploy recovered individuals who have developed protective antibodies to SARS-CoV-2. Serological testing is essential to identifying individuals who have been infected, recovered and are immune (in the near term) to SARS-CoV-2. Several scenarios have been explored that show substantive decreases in cases, hospitalizations, and deaths compared to baseline given enhanced interactions with recovered individuals that reduce the risk of transmission.
post_context: Policy implications Our findings reinforce the need for large-scale, serological testing initiatives to identify individuals who have recovered from COVID-19.While there are still uncertainties regarding the length and effectiveness of immunity, the strategic identification and utilization of recovered individuals present an opportunity to decrease transmission for the greater good. Implementing widespread serological testing initiatives is crucial for proactive strategies to end the COVID-19 pandemic and facilitate economic recovery, aiming to limit the final outbreak to less than 25% of the population infected, compared to the potential 90% without protective measures. Our core shielding model serves as the foundation for applying this concept to COVID-19, with the potential for further adjustments based on detailed mixing and substitution models in specific geographic areas or networks. In this analysis, we integrate our shield immunity model into the epidemiological dynamics of the COVID-19 crisis, focusing on susceptible, exposed, and infectious individuals, along with recovered individuals moving freely in a normal scenario. We also consider varying levels of hospitalization for symptomatic cases, including subacute and critical cases requiring ICU intervention, with a significant portion of critical cases resulting in mortality. We utilize age-specific data on hospitalization risk and acute cases from previous studies to inform our model's parameters. This novel approach, which incorporates shield immunity, diverges from traditional SIR models by accounting for social distancing measures.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: The main focus in controlling the spread of COVID-19 has been on mitigation and suppression measures, but questions remain about their sustainability and exit strategies. In addition to these approaches, we propose a 'shield immunity' model that utilizes serological tests to identify and utilize recovered individuals with protective antibodies to the virus. Serological testing is crucial for identifying those who are immune to COVID-19 in the short term. Our research suggests that interactions with recovered individuals can significantly reduce transmission, leading to decreases in cases, hospitalizations, and deaths. While our findings are based on certain assumptions, integrating seropositive individuals into intervention strategies could help better manage the epidemic.Policy implications Our findings reinforce the need for large-scale, serological testing initiatives to identify individuals who have recovered from COVID-19. Although questions remain about the duration and effectiveness of immunity, strategic identification and deployment of recovered individuals represents an opportunity to reduce transmission for the collective good. Initiating large-scale serological testing initiatives is key to proactive approaches to end the COVID-19 pandemic and enable economic re-engagement. ensuring  the  final  outbreak  concludes  with  less  than  25%  of  the population  having  been  infected  compared  to  the  expectation  of
post_context: in the absence of shielding.Our core shielding model serves as the foundation for our application to COVID-19, highlighting the conservative benefits of shielding. Additionally, more detailed mixing and substitution models could lead to different variations of this model in spatially explicit domains or on networks. Here, we apply our shield immunity model to the epidemiological dynamics of the COVID-19 pandemic, considering a population of susceptible, exposed, infectious asymptomatically, infectious symptomatically, and recovered individuals. We simplify by not accounting for births or other causes of death. Some symptomatic cases will require hospitalization, with subacute and critical/acute cases distinguished. We assume a portion of critical cases will result in death. The risk of hospitalization and acute cases are age-stratified based on previous data from the United Kingdom and the United States. Our model, which incorporates shield immunity, differs from traditional SIR models with social distancing or case isolation interventions. The transmission rate is reduced by a factor dependent on the population fraction and the number of recovered individuals within a specific age range. All recovered individuals are assumed to have immunity, but only some can facilitate interaction substitutions. It is also assumed that individuals in the circulating pool do not interact with hospitalized patients.

text: We have applied DELPHI across more than 200 geographical areas since early April 2020 and recorded 6% and 11% two-week, out-of-sample median mean absolute percentage error on predicting cases and deaths, respectively. DELPHI compares favorably with other top COVID-19 epidemiological models and predicted in 2020 the large-scale epidemics in many areas, including the United States, United Kingdom, and Russia, months in advance.

Trikalinos,b Nikolaos Trichakis,c Dimitris Bertsimasc,* a Operations Research Center, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02139; b Center for Evidence Synthesis in Health, Brown University, Providence, Rhode Island 02912; c Sloan School of Management, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02142 *Corresponding author Contact: mlli@mit.edu, oskali@mit.edu, (TAT); ntrichakis@mit.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8208-3035 (OSL); thomas_trikalinos@brown.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8324-9148 (NT); dbertsim@mit.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-2456-4834 (MLL); htazi@mit.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-3990-1848 https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1985-1003 (DB) https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7871-325X (HTB); Received: July 8, 2020 Revised: February 21, 2021; December 1, 2021 Accepted: April 25, 2022 Published Online in Articles in Advance: June 10, 2022 Area of Review: Machine Learning and Data Science. https://doi.org/10.1287/opre.2022.2306 Copyright: © 2022 INFORMS Abstract. We developed DELPHI, a novel epidemiological model for predicting detected cases and deaths in the prevaccination era of the COVID-19 pandemic. The model allows for underdetection of infections and effects of government interventions.
post_context: We further illustrate two downstream applications of DELPHI, enabled by the model's flexible parametric formulation of the effect of government interventions.Initially, we analyze the impact of government interventions on the spread of the pandemic. We estimate that without any interventions, over 14 million people would have died by May 17, 2020, but implementing interventions just a week earlier could have prevented 280,000 deaths globally. Our findings show that restrictions on mass gatherings and school closures led to the greatest reductions in infection rates, at 29.6% and 17.3% respectively. The most effective policy, stay-at-home orders, resulted in an average reduction in infection rates of 74.4% from the baseline for countries that implemented it. Furthermore, we demonstrate how the DELPHI model can forecast future COVID-19 cases under different government policies and highlight how Janssen Pharmaceuticals used this analysis to choose locations for its Phase III trial of the Ad26.Cov2.S vaccine. Additional information can be found in the e-companion at https://doi.org/10.1287/opre.2022.2306. Keywords: epidemiology, compartmental modeling, infectious diseases, partial identifiability. The COVID-19 pandemic, with over 530 million confirmed cases and 6.3 million deaths as of June 1, 2022, is the most deadly outbreak in recent memory. In March 2020, we introduced the DELPHI model, which builds on the classical SEIR model to forecast the pandemic's trajectory, account for underreported infections, and evaluate the impact of interventions. DELPHI has consistently been included in the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's core ensemble forecasts.
