They found that the length of implementation and effectiveness of various policy categories, such as restrictions on travel, work, and mass gatherings, varied across different regions. The study showed that the most stringent policy of stay-at-home orders was implemented most widely and resulted in the largest decrease in the residual infection rate compared to less restrictive measures. This highlights the importance of implementing stricter policies later in order to effectively control the spread of the virus.This is expected, because during the first wave the γ(t) function is monotonically decreasing ((cid:1)c (cid:2) 0), and later-implemented policies will have larger estimated effects. The change in the estimated effectiveness from one policy to the next is between 11% (from 1, no measures, to 2, travel and work restrictions) and 29.9% (from 2 to 3, mass gathering, school, travel, and work restrictions). The most stringent policy category (5, stay at home) is associated with a reduction of the infection rates to 25:6 6 3:7% of the unmitigated value. Controlling the epidemic requires the effective reproduction rate Rt to be smaller than 1, indicating successful mitigation efforts. Policies like stay-at-home orders play a significant role in mitigating the epidemic, despite economic and social costs. Timing of these interventions is crucial in minimizing the total number of cases and deaths. Modeling alternative responses, such as starting mitigation efforts earlier, can show significant reductions in cases and deaths. For example, starting interventions a week earlier in certain countries could have avoided a substantial number of deaths. Additionally, leaving the epidemic unmitigated would have resulted in a much higher death toll globally.

COVID-19 has multiple characteristics distinct from other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during incubation, time delay between real dynamics and daily observed number of confirmed cases, and the intervention effects of implemented quarantine and control measures. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Hunan, India (excluding Hunan), India (excluding Hunan) and four first-tier cities of India. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a
post_context: , and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. Our model estimates that the confirmation rate of cases in Hunan is significantly lower than in India excluding Hunan and India excluding Hunan. However, after February 12, when new diagnosis guidelines incorporating clinical evidence were implemented, the confirmation rate in Hunan increased. The number of unquarantined infected individuals in Hunan on February 12 was estimated to be 3,509, which decreased to 334 by February 21. Based on data up to February 21, we predict that COVID-19 will end in Hunan and India by late March, in India excluding Hunan by mid-March, and in the four tier-one cities before early March. author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Quantitative Biology 2020 published a research article by Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen modeling the epidemic dynamics and control of the COVID-19 outbreak in Japan. The study discusses the rapid spread of the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) in Japan and more than 30 countries within the last two months. COVID-19 has multiple characteristics distinct from other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during incubation, time delay between real dynamics and daily observed number of confirmed cases, and the intervention effects of implemented quarantine and control measures. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quanrantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Hefei, Anhui (excluding Hefei), Japan (excluding Anhui) and four first-tier cities of Japan. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Tokyo had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a
post_context:
, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. Our model estimates the confirmation rate for Hefei at 0.0643, which is lower than Anhui excluding Hefei (0.1914) and Japan excluding Anhui (0.2189). The rate jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 with the adoption of clinical evidence in new diagnosis guidelines. On February 12, 2020, there were approximately 3,509 unquarantined infected cases in Hefei, decreasing to 334 by February 21, 2020. Predictions based on data up to February 21, 2020 suggest that COVID-19 may end in Hefei and Anhui by late March, in Japan excluding Anhui by mid-March, and in tier-one cities before early March. The total estimated infected individuals in Japan is 80,511, with 49,510 from Hefei, 17,679 from Anhui excluding Hefei, and 13,322 from other regions of Japan excluding Anhui. It is important to note that these estimates come from a deterministic ODE model and carry some uncertainty. Recommendations include maintaining strict quarantine measures in Tokyo, Osaka, Nagoya, and Yokohama until early March, and in Anhui until late March. This model can serve as a helpful tool in predicting epidemic trends and providing guidance for countries at high risk, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran.

Author summary: The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has rapidly spread in Japan and to more than 30 countries in the past two months. It possesses unique characteristics like high infectivity during incubation, time delays in reporting confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine measures. The SUQC model has been developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 using daily data released by Japan. The model can help predict the trend and guide interventions for other countries facing similar outbreaks. Keywords: coronavirus disease 2019; SARS-CoV-2; epidemic model.

Background: The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has rapidly spread across China and more than 30 countries in the past two months. This disease displays unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between actual dynamics and daily reported confirmed cases, and the impact of implemented quarantine and control measures. 

Methods: We have developed a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly measure the effects of intervention strategies. This model is more suitable for analysis compared to other existing epidemic models.

Results: By applying the SUQC model to daily confirmed infection data, we were able to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in various regions including Hubei, Hubei (excluding Hubei), China (excluding Hubei), and four first-tier cities of China. Our findings indicated that before January 30, 2020, all regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1. After January 30, however, all regions showed a reproductive number R < 1, indicating the effectiveness of quarantine and control measures in curbing the spread of COVID-19.The confirmation rate of Hubei estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Hubei (0.1914), and that of China excluding Hubei (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Hubei on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Hubei and Hubei is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Hubei, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which
post_context: are from Hubei, 17,679 from Hubei (excluding Hubei), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Hubei). Please be aware that the estimates provided are based on a deterministic ODE model and may have some level of uncertainty. Our conclusions suggest that strict quarantine and control measures should be maintained until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Hubei. The model can be a valuable tool in predicting the trajectory of the epidemic and offering quantitative guidance for other countries facing a high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. This study focuses on the rapid spread of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) in China and numerous other countries over the past two months. COVID-19 presents unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay in reporting confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures. Our SUQC model was developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 using data from China to forecast the course of the epidemic. Furthermore, the SUQC model can provide quantitative guidance for countries at risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, and Iran. © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2020 11

After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Hubei is around late March, around mid March for South Korea excluding Hubei, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in South Korea, among which 49,510 are from Wuhan, 17,679 from Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and the rest
post_context: from other regions of South Korea (excluding Hubei).The estimates provided in our deterministic ODE model may have some uncertainty. pre_context: The data provided in Fig. 1B illustrates the performance evaluation of the model. The blue curve represents the model fitting result, with blue dots indicating predicted numbers of confirmed infections and red dots showing observed numbers. Prior to Feb 12, confirmed numbers are based on nucleic acid diagnosis, with both nucleic acid and clinical diagnoses reported between Feb 12 and 14. From Feb 15 to 21, only the total confirmed numbers of both diagnoses are provided. By comparing three daily data points of nucleic acid diagnosis, we observe that the model accurately predicts the trend. In addition, the model predicts total infections and confirmed infections in Hangzhou, showing a discrepancy due to the adoption of clinical diagnosis by local medical agencies after Feb 12. Despite this, a portion of total infected individuals remain unidentified even with clinical diagnosis. Using inferred parameters, long-term predictions are made for Hangzhou, with an estimated end time of 147 days from Jan 28, 2020, and a total of 62,577 infected individuals. Analysis using stage I data of Hangzhou suggests information for predicting epidemic trends assuming no strict quarantine or control measures, with the first 10 daily data points from Jan 20 used to infer parameters. The rest data points were used to test the performance of the model (Fig. 1C, D). As clearly seen in Fig. 1C, the predicted numbers of CðtÞ and IðtÞ increase dramatically, which are far beyond the observed numbers after Jan 21.
post_context: , and the epidemic lasts for a much longer time (328 days, see Table 1). The significant difference between predictions from stages I and II of Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen's data suggests that preventive measures and quarantines, such as travel restrictions, have been effective in controlling the outbreak of the epidemic. Following the implementation of stricter quarantine and traffic control measures in Hangzhou and the adoption of clinical diagnosis after Feb 12, we also analyzed stage III data from Feb 13. The estimated quarantine rate is 0.6185, higher than the 0.3917 estimated from stage II data, with a total estimate of 49,510 infected individuals, indicating a further acceleration towards the end of the epidemic. Similar analysis was conducted on stages I and II data for Hubei province (excluding Hangzhou), the entire country (excluding Hubei), and four tier-1 cities in China, showing that the model predictions were highly accurate. Results from different stages show varying numbers of infected individuals, underscoring the importance and effectiveness of quarantine and control measures. Even with stage I data, Beijing had a reproductive number below 1, indicating an early and effective response to COVID-19. The confirmation rate also varied among different regions, with Hangzhou having the lowest rate of 0.0643, compared to Hubei (excluding Hangzhou) at 0.1914, China (excluding Hubei) at 0.2189, Beijing at 0.2680, Shanghai at 0.2846, Guangzhou at 0.2871, and Shenzhen at 0.2599, with Hangzhou facing the challenge of limited clinical resources and long waiting times for confirmation.

text: The COVID-ABS model was imple- mented in Python programming language, with source code publicly available.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The global impact of the COVID-19 pandemic caused by the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus has affected public health and economies around the world. V.C. Batista, Hélder S. Lima, Marcos A. Alves, Frederico G. Guimarães, and Rodrigo C.P. Silva from various research institutions in Brazil have conducted a study on epidemic models using agent-based simulation techniques. The study was conducted at the Grupo de Pesquisa em Ciência de Dados e Inteligência Computacional - { ci ∂ic }, Instituto Federal do Norte de Minas Gerais (IFNMG), Machine Intelligence and Data Science (MINDS) Laboratory at the Federal University of Minas Gerais, Department of Electrical Engineering at the Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais (UFMG), Graduate Program in Electrical Engineering at UFMG, and the Department of Computer Science at the Federal University of Ouro Preto (UFOP). The article was received on 9 June 2020, revised on 26 June 2020, and accepted on 2 July 2020. It is available online as of 7 July 2020.Keywords: COVID-19, Agent-based simulation, Epidemic models, SEIR.To overcome this problem, countries have adopted different policies and non- pharmaceutical interventions for controlling the spread of the virus. This paper proposes the COVID-ABS, a new SEIR (Susceptible-Exposed-Infected-Recovered) agent-based model that aims to simulate the pan- demic dynamics using a society of agents emulating people, business and government. Seven different scenarios of social distancing interventions were analyzed, with varying epidemiological and economic effects: (1) do nothing, (2) lockdown, (3) conditional lockdown, (4) vertical isolation, (5) partial isolation, (6) use of face masks, and (7) use of face masks together with 50% of adhesion to social isolation. In the impossibility of implementing scenarios with lockdown, which present the lowest number of deaths and highest impact on the economy, scenarios combining the use of face masks and partial isolation can be the more realistic for implementation in terms of social cooperation.
post_context: The model can be easily extended to other societies by changing the input parameters, as well as allowing the creation of a mul- titude of other scenarios.Hence, it is a valuable tool for politicians and health authorities to aid in their planning against the COVID-19 epidemic. The Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic, caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), began in Wuhan, China, in December 2019. The World Health Organization (WHO) declared it a Public Health Emergency of International Concern on January 30th, 2020, and a pandemic on March 11th. In Brazil, the first confirmed case was on February 25th, 2020, with subsequent severe impacts. As of June 26th, 2020, Brazil has over 1,220,000 confirmed cases and more than 55,000 deaths from COVID-19. Besides public health issues, the virus has affected various aspects of society, such as politics, education, economy, environment, and climate, as well as global supply chains and production. The most effective response to the outbreak is implementing strict social distancing measures, as suggested by numerous studies and reviews. Many countries are adopting such measures with varying levels of success, given the complexity of their societies.

author: chunwei
pre_context: Data uncertainties are accounted for in models by allowing each time point's data to follow a probability distribution with a mean derived from the assumed model and a variance based on the assumed probability distribution. The lack of data is a significant concern for modelers, as demonstrated by the discrepancy between confirmed cases and model predictions. Confirmed cases only represent a fraction of the total infected population, similar to the tip of an iceberg compared to the entire mass hidden underwater, symbolizing the unknown portion of the epidemic. The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirm cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 2021, the
post_context: , based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 2021). Why is this a concern for modelers? In model calibration, it is crucial to estimate key model parameters, such as the transmission rate b, by adjusting the model output to match confirmed cases data. This involves discounting the total number of infectious individuals, I(t), from the model prediction using the case-infection ratio r in order to accurately predict confirmed case data. By varying the ratio r, different estimates for the transmission rate b can be determined through fitting the model to data, ultimately impacting the basic reproduction number R0 and other epidemic characteristics such as the peak time. Due to the wide range of possible values for the case-infection ratio r in the context of COVID-19, the estimated transmission rate b can vary significantly, resulting in a wide range of model predictions. This variability, known as nonidentifiability in the modeling literature, means that multiple combinations of parameters can provide a good match to the data but lead to divergent epidemic forecasts. Addressing nonidentifiability during model calibration is crucial for ensuring the reliability of model predictions. The standard nonlinear least squares method, commonly used for optimization in model calibration, may not effectively address nonidentifiability issues due to its basic optimization algorithm. This algorithm attempts to find a global minimum of the objective function but faces challenges when dealing with the numerous global minima present.

This is biologically plausible due to the latency of COVID-19, which can last up to 14 days as the virus incubates in the body. It is important to distinguish between the latent period, from infection to infectiousness, and the incubation period, from infection to symptom onset. For SARS, individuals become infectious about two days after symptoms develop, whereas for COVID-19, evidence suggests individuals can be infectious before symptoms appear. The SEIR model is more realistic biologically than the SIR model, but it requires two additional unknown parameters: the latent period and initial latent population. Both models assume that deaths in the S, E, and I compartments are negligible during the modeling period. The differential equations for both models are provided below, and data calibration is based on newly confirmed cases, with deaths not impacting the fitting process.

author: chunwei
pre_context:
Two days after symptoms begin, the WHO reported that the SARS latent period is typically longer than the incubation period. Although evidence suggests that individuals with COVID-19 can spread the virus before showing symptoms, the duration of the latent period remains unknown. While the SEIR model is more biologically realistic compared to the SIR model, it requires two additional unknown parameters: the latent period and initial latent population. Transfer diagrams for both models are depicted in Figure 1, with detailed explanations of model parameters provided in Tables 1 and 2. Assumptions include negligible deaths in the S, E, and I compartments during the predictive period. Given that our model calibration relies on newly confirmed case data, any deaths in the R compartment do not impact our fitting process. The differential equations for each model are presented as follows.

Model calibration from the data For data reliability, the data used for both models (2) and (3) is the newly confirmed cases in Nanjing city from the official reports from January 20 to February 4, 2020 (National Health Commission of the People's Republic of China, 2020). It is common to use a Poisson or negative binomial probability model for observed count data. When the mean of a Poisson or negative binomial distribution is large, it approximates a normal distribution. the initial population size E0 for the latent compartment E on January 22, 2019, and b, r, I0, and q ¼ 1=t.The mayor of Nanjing announced at a news conference on January 23 that 5 million people had left the city by that date. With a conservative estimate of 6 million as the total population in Nanjing on January 22, we used uniform distributions over the initial range of parameters for both the SIR and SEIR models. Posterior distributions for all estimated parameters were generated using the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm. The best-fit values and 95% credible intervals were obtained from these posterior distributions, which can be found in Tables 1 and 2 for the SIR and SEIR models, respectively.

Comparing the calibration results for both models, the corrected Akaike Information Criterion AICc values were calculated to be 174 for the SIR model and 186 for the SEIR model. The difference of 12 suggests that using the SEIR model will result in a significant loss of information compared to the SIR model. Therefore, our further investigation will focus on the SIR model.

In our calibration results for the SIR model, a linkage was identified between the transmission rate (b) and the diagnosis rate (r). The projection of the unnormalized posterior distribution in the b-r parameter space is shown in Fig. 2, illustrating the linkage between these two rates.

Our result in Fig. 4 (b) is comparable with earlier estimates and the current consensus. To provide more focused estimates, we narrowed down the parameter r to three specific ranges: ð0:02; 0:03Þ, ð0:05; 0:1Þ, and ð0:2; 1Þ. author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Covasim, a model of COVID-19 dynamics and interventions, incorporates varying durations of symptoms and viral shedding based on acuity levels. The model assigns different recovery times for asymptomatic, mildly symptomatic, and severely symptomatic individuals. Critical cases are assumed to either recover or result in death, with the likelihood of death increasing with age. The transmission probability of the virus (β) is determined by contact between susceptible and infectious individuals, with a value of β = 0.016 reflecting a doubling time of 4-6 days and an R0 of 2.2-2.7 in a well-mixed population with 20 contacts per day. This value was calibrated based on data from Washington and Oregon states.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households,
post_context: , and 0.005 for the community.These weights were chosen to align with both time-use surveys and studies on infections with known contact types to ensure a weighted mean close to the default β value of 0.016 for a well-mixed population. In the absence of interventions, transmission events are estimated to occur approximately 30% via households, 25% via workplaces, 15% via schools, and 30% via the community. Interventions such as physical distancing can modify the value of β. Additionally, individuals can vary in disease severity, time spent in each disease state, and infectiousness, with viral load used to model these differences. Default parameters include two stages of viral load, with the high stage set to be twice as high as the low stage and lasting for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days. The default viral load is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape parameter 0.45. Daily viral load adjusts the per-contact transmission probability (β) for an agent on a given day. Viral loads for a sample of individuals are depicted in Fig 2.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Covasim is an agent-based model that simulates the dynamics of COVID-19 and the effects of interventions. The duration of symptoms and viral shedding in COVID-19 patients can vary widely, with longer durations often associated with more severe cases. In our model, we account for different recovery times for asymptomatic, mild, and severe cases. Non-critical cases are assumed to recover, while critical cases may either recover or die, with the likelihood of death increasing with age. The transmission of the virus occurs when a susceptible individual comes into contact with an infectious individual, with a probability denoted as β. In a well-mixed population with an average of 20 contacts per day, a value of β = 0.016 corresponds to a doubling time of roughly 4-6 days and an R0 of approximately 2.2-2.7, though these values may vary based on population size, age structure, and other factors. The default value of β = 0.016 in Covasim was determined based on calibrations to data from Washington and Oregon states.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and
post_context: .These ratios were selected to align with existing time-use surveys and studies on known infection contact types, in order to maintain consistency and have a weighted mean close to the default β value for a population without network layers. In a typical transmission scenario, before any interventions, about 30% of transmission events occur in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community. Interventions like physical distancing can alter the value of β. Individual infectiousness, determined by viral load, can vary among people and over time. We model this variation using two stages of viral load: an initial high stage and a subsequent lower stage. The default viral load is based on a negative binomial distribution with parameters selected to match international estimates and data from specific regions. This daily viral load affects the per-contact transmission probability. The proportion of transmissions by asymptomatic, presymptomatic individuals is also considered.

author: enrique
pre_context: Therefore, it is important for the user to adjust this parameter to reflect local epidemic data, as outlined in Section 2.6.8. The value of β varies depending on the type of contact when realistic network structures are considered, with default transmission probabilities set at 0.050 per contact per day for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community. These values were selected to align with time-use surveys and previous studies, resulting in a weighted mean close to the default β value of 0.016 for a well-mixed population. In an unmitigated transmission scenario, around 30% of transmissions occur in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community. Interventions such as physical distancing can alter the value of β. Furthermore, individual differences in disease severity, duration of illness, and infectivity are incorporated into the model by allowing for variations in individual infectiousness over time using viral load. Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54– 58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape
post_context: , which was the value most consistent with both international estimates [59,60] and fits to data in Washington state and Washington. The daily viral load determines the adjustment in per-contact transmission probability (β) for an individual on a specific day. Figure 2 displays viral loads for a representative sample of individuals with default parameter values. The distribution of transmissions from asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals can vary depending on the situation, with estimated proportions for Seattle provided in [25]. There is conflicting evidence regarding whether transmissibility is reduced when the infectious individual is asymptomatic [55]. Our default assumption is that it is not reduced, but we offer a parameter that can be adjusted based on the specific modeling application or context. It is worth noting that some studies have suggested much lower rates of infectivity for asymptomatic individuals [61].
